i still headcanon that the youngest stark is still alive. That the boy at the BOTB was not rickon stark but Jon and Sansa played along and acted as if he was. Vasically my headcanon is that the fArya storyline was adapted into the fRickon storyline. and Jon and Sansa know it through their dreams or whatever.

summary: Game of Thrones: I'll be brutal and merciless from the start, killing off everyone's favorite characters or at least doing them...
body:
Game of Thrones: I’ll be brutal and merciless from the start, killing off everyone’s favorite characters or at least doing them serious harm, so fans will know not to expect a happy ending from me. They’re just so devoted… I wouldn’t wanna mislead any of them.

Merlin: I’ll be sweet and playful at the start, only killing off characters who deserve it, and always saving the good guys from serious harm, so when fans are sure of a happy ending… I’ll stab them in the fucking eye. In both eyes. Twice. Fucking morons.

summary: Wrath of the Dragon Merry Christmas @adecila! It is I, your secret santa. I have revealed myself! I hope you like it, keep in...
body:
Wrath of the Dragon

  • Merry Christmas @adecila! It is I, your secret santa. I have revealed myself! I hope you like it, keep in mind, this is only the first chapter of a series. :3

Word Count: 3.6k ︱ A/N: Just so you know, Jon Snow is Aegon Targaryen. But his brother is also Aegon, I understand if it’s a little complicated, just bear with me through this first chapter. :3

Rheagar Targaryen

She was born while the bells of King’s Landing rang, loud and clear amid the storm that swallowed the shores. The thunderous claps of the sky filled the ears of the people in the city, along with Rheagar’s who watched as his little sister was born; a silver haired beauty with puffy pink lips, swollen from the journey she made into the world.

He watched as his mother lay in the birthing bed, unmoving and stiff. The color from her rose kissed cheeks was dulling to a pale white as blood soaked into the fine sheets that would take the servants weeks to wash out. He would have to burn them, he didn’t want them around. He didn’t want to remember how he lost his mother.

The gods, if there were any, were cruel to take his mother from him in the same fashion that they took his beloved, Lyanna.

He recalled that night all too well. The way she whimpered quietly as she pleaded with Rhaegar to take care of her child. How she cried softly at the sight of the raven-haired boy gently nestled in Rheagar’s strong arms. And then the quiet intake of her last breath as the Stranger took her.

In the empty halls of the Red Keep, the wind whistled, and the rain pattered against the hard stone, he could vaguely hear the whisper of her voice once more. Of his Lyanna, his winter rose.

The whispers were drowned out by the sounds of his father’s shouting coming from his own room, “Burn them all!”

He sighed heavily as he held his little sister in his hands, his mind feeling as though it would sooner fall out of its place in his skull the longer, he heard the shouts. He wondered if he could quell the unrest that was stirring within the kingdoms.

It was no secret that King Aerys was… unruly. Even he was filled with unease whenever the thought that his father might become more unhinged plagued him.

In the darkness, in his own quarters that he shared with Lyanna, he knew his own son, Aegon, slept soundly.

So close in age.

One of fire, and one of ice.

He took after his mother, with the dark hair and the dark eyes. He was a northerner. A true northerner. If there was a splash of his own Targaryen blood within his own child, it would be in his character. It would be in how he chose to lead.

He had to do something. Not just for his sister, or his son, but for the people of Westeros. He had to take the throne from his father and rule, as much as he dreaded it. As much as he’d rather lay in the ground with his beloved Lyanna, he had to fulfill his destiny. As did his sister. His brother. And his son.

“Burn them all!”

The words made him cringe inside, and cool chill traveled up his spine as he slowly closed his eyes, sighing heavily with sorrow.

Gently, he handed his baby sister, Daenerys, to the wet nurse that watched him with sad eyes, “See to it that she’s well taken care of. I will be back for her in the morning.”

“Of course, Your Grace,” the older lady squeaked as she took the child from him.

Like the proud prince that he was, his head held high and the Targaryen blood of the dragon flowing though him, he glided his way to his father’s quarters, his resolve stiff and true.

He had to do the right thing.



Aegon Targaryen

A boy of ten with a full head of curls and deep brown eyes watched the young girl with flowing silver hair from the other end of the table as she practiced her penmanship. She sat beside his brother, Egg, and his sister Rhaenys. But his attention wasn’t on them, it was on her; he watched as her delicate hand curved the letters on the parchment, glistening with ink in the bright sunlight that shone through the open courtyard as Grand Maester Pycelle droned on about the lineage and ancestry of the Targaryens, and their dominion over Westeros.

It was a story he’d heard many times before, he could recite the stories in his head word for word the way Grand Maester Pycelle spoke them, in his old, exhausted, heavy voice.

The Grand Maester’s words were echoes in his ears, his eyes focused on the girl as she listened intently to what the old man said, although she had heard them many times before. She remained patient, in awe, as if all of this was the first time, she had heard it spoken. She loved the stories, he recalled. She had told him as such. She had always dreamed of having her own dragons to ride, of course, that would be impossible.

All the dragons were dead.

“I, I must say it is time for a spot of lunch,” Pycelle droned, bringing Jon out of his thought process, aware that Daenerys’ eyes immediately shot up to meet his. His eyes darted to the stones on the ground, watching the toes of his fine leather boots with too much concentration.

He could feel her watching him with those kind violet eyes of hers. From the corner of his eye, he could see the gentlest of smiles begin to cross her puffy, pink lips.

“Egg Jon!”

His head immediately shot up to glance at Viserys Targaryen gallanting towards him, wooden swords clutched in each hand. He stared at the boy, almost with envy. Viserys was his uncle, and though the silver haired boy was 5 years older than he, and they were rivaled in the art of swordsmanship, everyone secretly agreed that Aegon was better.

But he had the regal Targaryen look that his father had; violet eyes, silver hair. They were beautiful, there was no denying that. And Viserys made sure to remind him that he was an outsider.

“You’re not a true Targaryen, look at you, you don’t even have the looks of a king,” he would say as he puffed his chest out and adjusted his silks and leather, “Not like me.”

Aegon turned and glanced down at the drying ink on parchment as he worked on his penmanship, “What do you want Viserys?”

“Let’s spar,” he said, tapping him on the back with a wooden sword, “C’mon, I’ve been practicing, and I need someone to knock into the dirt.”

“I’m busy,” Aegon sighed, writing his name on the parchment.

Aegon Targaryen.

Why did father name him and his half-brother the same name?

He couldn’t figure it out, and his father refused to talk about it. Nevertheless, Viserys was the first person to begin calling him Jon, it began as a simple mispronunciation, though he would never admit it.

Eh-Jon was how he pronounced it, not Egg-On.

Since then, the name stuck. But he knew better, as time went on, Viserys meant it more as an insult.

Viserys glanced down at the markings on the parchment, “Just like your footwork, your linework is awful. I suppose that’s what happens when a Targaryen tumbles with a northerner. I heard they’re all savages—”

“Shut your mouth, Viserys.”

The room went silent. Daenerys, who was sitting across the table from him stared up at the boys with wide, worried eyes. Rhaenys and his brother, Egg, tensed, and slowly readied themselves for a fight; Aegon wasn’t the only one that was a victim of Viserys’ constant bullying. Grand Maester Pycelle breathed heavily as he began, “N-now children—”

A sudden sting shot up from his hand to his arm as the wooden sword came down on him, hard. Jon shouted in agony, and in an instant, Viserys was on the ground as Jon’s fist connected with his stupid, kingly face.

Stupid boy.

Stupid silver haired boy.

Stupid Targaryens.

Viserys shouted, bringing up the wooden sword and hitting him across the face with it, but Jon continued pummeling his fist into the silver haired boy’s face until he felt strong hands beneath him, he kicked and thrashed in the arms of the man who carried him, fighting to be set free to  beat the smug Viserys within an inch of his life.

Amidst the chaos and the shouting, he lost interest in Viserys Targaryen. His own eyes fell on another pair of violet eyes, eyes that glanced at him with sorrow and remorse as she kneeled beside her brother, brushing his hair back in her hands.


“A prince does not behave in such a manner,” his father lectured.

Once King Rhaegar Targaryen heard of the altercation, Aegon knew he would be in trouble. His father consistently reminded him and reprimanded him when he behaved as anything other than the Prince he was, and the King he was going to become.

“He said my mother was a savage,” Aegon pouted, kicking the wooden beam of his four-poster canopy bed, “I should have cut his tongue out like Ser Illyn’s—”

“That’s enough, Aegon!”

Jon paused in his steps, jumping up slightly from the sound of his father’s raised voice. Rhaegar Targaryen very rarely raised his voice at him, so he knew now that he had crossed a line.

“Forgive me, father, I was—”

“There’s nothing to forgive, child,” his father said, beckoning him to take a seat beside him on the soft, feather bed. Aegon slowly dragged his feet towards the bed, jumping up beside his father as he placed a strong arm around his small shoulders, “Viserys is your uncle, and as wrong as it was for him to say what he said, that does not warrant a reaction from you. If you are to be a King one day, you need to learn to take what others have to say about you in stride, you are above words.”

“He said I wasn’t a real Targaryen, because I don’t look like you.”

“Look at me,” his father ordered. Hesitantly, Aegon looked up into his father’s vibrant violet eyes, “You are a Targaryen. You have the blood of the dragon, but you’re also a wolf, just as your mother was. That does not change the fact that you will rule, and with ruling comes being wise to choose your battles, and strong enough to avoid the words that others have to say about you. You will marry Rhaenys, and together you will continue to build the Targaryen dynasty.”

Aegon’s brows furrowed at the words, “Rhaenys?”

“Are you not pleased?”

“It’s not— I just— why Rhaenys?”

His father’s silver brows crinkled at his question, “The Targaryens have always wed members of their families—”

“But you married my mother. And before that, Lady Elia. They weren’t members of your family,” Aegon pointed.

He could see the unrest in his father as he rubbed his face with his hand, smirking to himself in amusement, “Is this about Daenerys?”

“What? NO!” Jon shouted in embarrassment.

“I know you’re upset that Viserys is to marry her, I know that’s the reason why you’re not too fond of him and why you fight him every opportunity you get,” he said.

“I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

“Be that as it may, Daenerys is to wed Viserys when they come of age, and you will wed Rhaenys. She is of Dornish descent, and they did not take too kindly the fact that I annulled my marriage to Lady Elia. You must fix the mess I created with them.”

“Was it a mistake then, marrying my mother and having me?”

Aegon felt his father’s strong arms tighten around him, “You and your mother were never, and will never be mistakes.”

Aegon looked down at his feet, nodding. He wasn’t sure if he felt better, or worse.

“No more fighting with Viserys, promise me,” his father ordered.

Sighing, Aegon reluctantly nodded, “I promise.”

“Good, and I will make certain he puts an end to his vile behavior as well. In the meantime, you are confined to your quarters to think about what we’ve talked about and you’ve done. I’ll have the servants bring your supper.”

For hours after, the young boy stared up at the canopy of his bed, bored and frustrated with being locked in his room. The food that the servants brought him remained untouched on the table across his bed.

The sound of the gentle rapping coming from his door nudged him from his thoughtful stupor; his brows knitted in confusion when he saw her tiny figure emerge, a candle in her hand as she made her way towards his bed. He sat up, staring at the little girl with wide eyes, “Daenerys? What are you doing here?”

“I wanted to see how you were doing,” she whispered, bringing the candlelight to his face, observing the small marks that Viserys left on him, “You’re doing a lot better than Viserys.”

“Are you here to tell me I shouldn’t have—”

“I’m not here to tell you anything, other than sorry for what he said,” she gently said.

Aegon’s eyes narrowed in confusion, “Why are you sorry? It’s not your fault.”

“He’s jealous of you.”

“That still doesn’t have anything to do with you.”

“He knows you like me, Aegon,” she spoke, making the boy flinch at her boldness.

He swallowed hard as he stared at her, his voice a slight whisper as he replied, “That doesn’t give him a reason to be jealous.”

She smiled softly, placing the candle holder on the table next to the bed and crossing her legs as she leaned in, whispering a secret, “You’re going to be the King of the Seven Kingdoms, of all of Westeros, and he’s not. He thinks he deserves it more than you.”

“I don’t want to be king.”

“You’re going to be.”

Aegon’s deep brown eyes bore into the light, violet crystals that were Daenerys’s eyes. How could he not like her?

She was always beautiful, and kind. And bold. She was the only one who didn’t treat him as an outsider; even Rhaenys and Egg treated him like an outsider.

But not her.

“But I don’t want to.”

“We all have to do things we don’t want to, Aegon.”

His eyes flew back up to hers, “Like marry Viserys?”

He watched her tense at his name, and Aegon narrowed his eyes suspiciously, “I’ll do what I have to do. We’re Targaryens, and we all have a destiny.”

Aegon continued to stare at her as she was lost in deep thought, her brows furrowed and her fingers picking at the ends of her nightgown. Finally, she sighed and reached for her candle, “I must go, before I get into trouble.”

“Okay,” Jon sighed, heavily as he watched her carefully jump from the bed and tiptoe towards the door, “Daenerys?”

She turned, the candlelight reflecting her eyes like a pair of deep amethyst jewels, “Yes?”

He wasn’t sure if he should ask it. And he wasn’t sure if she would even tell him the truth if he had, but he wanted to. He wanted to so badly to know if she felt the same way about him, the way he did about her.

Instead, he exhaled, defeated as he simply said, “Goodnight.”

She smiled, kindly and warmly at him, “Goodnight, Prince Aegon.”


It was late, very late into the night when Aegon heard footsteps and the silent creaking of his door being pushed open. The room was dark, but in the darkness, he could feel the shadows moving across his bedroom floor.

His father always warned him to be prepared, because no one is ever safe, not even in their sleep. He reached for the dagger underneath his pillow, ready to fight whomever dared to enter the Prince’s bedroom.

He could hear breathing, heavy breathing, as though someone was carrying a large weight over his shoulders. He heard a flint being struck, and as the light of the candle went aflame, he grasped his dagger and immediately swung into the air in front of him, missing the man’s tunic by a mere inch.

“Is that how you greet the men who are trying to save your life?”

Aegon’s brows furrowed. He recognized that voice, “Lord Varys? What are you—”

“I know you have questions, my young prince, but time is of the essence and unfortunately, I don’t have time to answer all of them,” the bald man said as he nodded to the men on the other side of the bed, who tossed a body on the bed beside him.

Aegon jumped in surprise, watching as they unwrapped the body from the cloaks. The boy, whom no doubt was dead, bared a striking resemblance to him. His hair was dark, curly. His skin was the same ivory tone as his own, “What—what is this?”

“We’re saving your life, Your Grace. We need to get you out of King’s Landing, immediately.”

“But—”

“Your father is dead, if he hasn’t been murdered in his sleep he will be soon. And you along with him,” Varys said as he watched the men prepare the boy in the bed, laying him there, watching as the blood in his body now seeped into his clean sheets.

“My—my father? We need to do something! We need to—”

“I am doing the only thing I can do; I can’t save him, but I can save you. You can come with me now, or you can stay here and die.”

Aegon glanced down at the body beside him.

This could be you.

Everything inside of him told him to stand and fight. To go and protect his father, to live up to his name. But he was good with a sword, that didn’t mean he was the best swordsman alive. He would be cut to pieces if he dared to take on the phantom enemies in the castle.

There was a part of him that didn’t believe the spider, but there was also something like concern in the spymaster’s face. He had never seen him look so concerned.

Reluctantly, Aegon pushed the blankets off him and pulled the cloak that Lord Varys handed to him over his shoulders, bringing the hood down over his face until Varys was satisfied that he would not easily be identified.

He followed Lord Varys and the gang of men out of his chambers, the castle was silent as they proceeded in the darkness, occasionally pausing as they heard footsteps in the halls and hiding in a dark corner until it was safe to pass.

He was led down parts of the castle he didn’t know existed, plunging down further and further into the darkness until they eventually emerged into a small channel with a small rowboat bobbing in the water quietly, “This is where I leave you, Prince Aegon.”

“What? Why—”

“You will be safe with these men, they will take you somewhere far away, somewhere safe. There, you will learn the truth of what has happened tonight,” he said, “One day, you will return. But for now, stay hidden. Don’t speak to anyone about who you are, your life depends on it.”

He watched with confused eyes as the men rowed him further and further out into the sea, the moonlight gleaming down on them, bathing them in a silver glow. The further they rowed out, the cleared the Red Keep became, and it was when he heard the bells begin to toll, that he knew Lord Varys spoke the truth about his father.

Who would want to kill Rhaegar Targaryen?

What about his brother? His sister? Daenerys?

“Wait, we need to go back,” he ordered.

“Can’t do that little lad,” one of the rowers said, “Orders were to get you out, only you.”

“We need to! I left someone behind—”

“If we go back, you’ll die—”

“I don’t care! I need to go back for her! I need to protect her!”

Aegon began thrashing in the rowboat, readying himself to jump out and swim back to the red keep for her. But the strong arms around him kept him from doing so. He shouted, screamed, and begged for them to return, but every minute they moved further from the keep and out into the vast openness of the sea.

Once the Keep was nothing but a small speck in the distance, he stopped fighting and resigned himself to his tears, thinking of those violet eyes, and the silver hair he would never see again. Thinking of the puffy pink lips he would never kiss.

The soft hands he would never feel against his skin.

Her gentle smile that always made him feel weak and tremble.

He thought about her; about all the times they played together, all the times she helped him work on his penmanship, all the times she told him she wished she could sword fight, and he obliged, handing her his wooden sword and teaching her the ways of swordsmanship.

He was vaguely aware of being pushed up the ladder of the side of ship, he didn’t pay any mind to the sails, or the colors of the sails. All he could think of was his father, and her.

The Keep was not visible from where he was now, all he saw was the moonlight reflecting the surface of the water in a silver light, like the color of her hair.

His breathing was heavy as he lowered his hood and stared up at the moon, making a silent promise not only to himself, but to his father, and to her.

If you’re alive, I’ll come back for you.

It was all he could do as he sailed out in the unknown, in the middle of the night.

Wrath of the Dragon

  • Merry Christmas @adecila! It is I, your secret santa. I have revealed myself! I hope you like it, keep in mind, this is only the first chapter of a series. :3

Word Count: 3.6k ︱ A/N: Just so you know, Jon Snow is Aegon Targaryen. But his brother is also Aegon, I understand if it’s a little complicated, just bear with me through this first chapter. :3

Rheagar Targaryen

She was born while the bells of King’s Landing rang, loud and clear amid the storm that swallowed the shores. The thunderous claps of the sky filled the ears of the people in the city, along with Rheagar’s who watched as his little sister was born; a silver haired beauty with puffy pink lips, swollen from the journey she made into the world.

He watched as his mother lay in the birthing bed, unmoving and stiff. The color from her rose kissed cheeks was dulling to a pale white as blood soaked into the fine sheets that would take the servants weeks to wash out. He would have to burn them, he didn’t want them around. He didn’t want to remember how he lost his mother.

The gods, if there were any, were cruel to take his mother from him in the same fashion that they took his beloved, Lyanna.

He recalled that night all too well. The way she whimpered quietly as she pleaded with Rhaegar to take care of her child. How she cried softly at the sight of the raven-haired boy gently nestled in Rheagar’s strong arms. And then the quiet intake of her last breath as the Stranger took her.

In the empty halls of the Red Keep, the wind whistled, and the rain pattered against the hard stone, he could vaguely hear the whisper of her voice once more. Of his Lyanna, his winter rose.

The whispers were drowned out by the sounds of his father’s shouting coming from his own room, “Burn them all!”

He sighed heavily as he held his little sister in his hands, his mind feeling as though it would sooner fall out of its place in his skull the longer, he heard the shouts. He wondered if he could quell the unrest that was stirring within the kingdoms.

It was no secret that King Aerys was… unruly. Even he was filled with unease whenever the thought that his father might become more unhinged plagued him.

In the darkness, in his own quarters that he shared with Lyanna, he knew his own son, Aegon, slept soundly.

So close in age.

One of fire, and one of ice.

He took after his mother, with the dark hair and the dark eyes. He was a northerner. A true northerner. If there was a splash of his own Targaryen blood within his own child, it would be in his character. It would be in how he chose to lead.

He had to do something. Not just for his sister, or his son, but for the people of Westeros. He had to take the throne from his father and rule, as much as he dreaded it. As much as he’d rather lay in the ground with his beloved Lyanna, he had to fulfill his destiny. As did his sister. His brother. And his son.

“Burn them all!”

The words made him cringe inside, and cool chill traveled up his spine as he slowly closed his eyes, sighing heavily with sorrow.

Gently, he handed his baby sister, Daenerys, to the wet nurse that watched him with sad eyes, “See to it that she’s well taken care of. I will be back for her in the morning.”

“Of course, Your Grace,” the older lady squeaked as she took the child from him.

Like the proud prince that he was, his head held high and the Targaryen blood of the dragon flowing though him, he glided his way to his father’s quarters, his resolve stiff and true.

He had to do the right thing.



Aegon Targaryen

A boy of ten with a full head of curls and deep brown eyes watched the young girl with flowing silver hair from the other end of the table as she practiced her penmanship. She sat beside his brother, Egg, and his sister Rhaenys. But his attention wasn’t on them, it was on her; he watched as her delicate hand curved the letters on the parchment, glistening with ink in the bright sunlight that shone through the open courtyard as Grand Maester Pycelle droned on about the lineage and ancestry of the Targaryens, and their dominion over Westeros.

It was a story he’d heard many times before, he could recite the stories in his head word for word the way Grand Maester Pycelle spoke them, in his old, exhausted, heavy voice.

The Grand Maester’s words were echoes in his ears, his eyes focused on the girl as she listened intently to what the old man said, although she had heard them many times before. She remained patient, in awe, as if all of this was the first time, she had heard it spoken. She loved the stories, he recalled. She had told him as such. She had always dreamed of having her own dragons to ride, of course, that would be impossible.

All the dragons were dead.

“I, I must say it is time for a spot of lunch,” Pycelle droned, bringing Jon out of his thought process, aware that Daenerys’ eyes immediately shot up to meet his. His eyes darted to the stones on the ground, watching the toes of his fine leather boots with too much concentration.

He could feel her watching him with those kind violet eyes of hers. From the corner of his eye, he could see the gentlest of smiles begin to cross her puffy, pink lips.

“Egg Jon!”

His head immediately shot up to glance at Viserys Targaryen gallanting towards him, wooden swords clutched in each hand. He stared at the boy, almost with envy. Viserys was his uncle, and though the silver haired boy was 5 years older than he, and they were rivaled in the art of swordsmanship, everyone secretly agreed that Aegon was better.

But he had the regal Targaryen look that his father had; violet eyes, silver hair. They were beautiful, there was no denying that. And Viserys made sure to remind him that he was an outsider.

“You’re not a true Targaryen, look at you, you don’t even have the looks of a king,” he would say as he puffed his chest out and adjusted his silks and leather, “Not like me.”

Aegon turned and glanced down at the drying ink on parchment as he worked on his penmanship, “What do you want Viserys?”

“Let’s spar,” he said, tapping him on the back with a wooden sword, “C’mon, I’ve been practicing, and I need someone to knock into the dirt.”

“I’m busy,” Aegon sighed, writing his name on the parchment.

Aegon Targaryen.

Why did father name him and his half-brother the same name?

He couldn’t figure it out, and his father refused to talk about it. Nevertheless, Viserys was the first person to begin calling him Jon, it began as a simple mispronunciation, though he would never admit it.

Eh-Jon was how he pronounced it, not Egg-On.

Since then, the name stuck. But he knew better, as time went on, Viserys meant it more as an insult.

Viserys glanced down at the markings on the parchment, “Just like your footwork, your linework is awful. I suppose that’s what happens when a Targaryen tumbles with a northerner. I heard they’re all savages—”

“Shut your mouth, Viserys.”

The room went silent. Daenerys, who was sitting across the table from him stared up at the boys with wide, worried eyes. Rhaenys and his brother, Egg, tensed, and slowly readied themselves for a fight; Aegon wasn’t the only one that was a victim of Viserys’ constant bullying. Grand Maester Pycelle breathed heavily as he began, “N-now children—”

A sudden sting shot up from his hand to his arm as the wooden sword came down on him, hard. Jon shouted in agony, and in an instant, Viserys was on the ground as Jon’s fist connected with his stupid, kingly face.

Stupid boy.

Stupid silver haired boy.

Stupid Targaryens.

Viserys shouted, bringing up the wooden sword and hitting him across the face with it, but Jon continued pummeling his fist into the silver haired boy’s face until he felt strong hands beneath him, he kicked and thrashed in the arms of the man who carried him, fighting to be set free to  beat the smug Viserys within an inch of his life.

Amidst the chaos and the shouting, he lost interest in Viserys Targaryen. His own eyes fell on another pair of violet eyes, eyes that glanced at him with sorrow and remorse as she kneeled beside her brother, brushing his hair back in her hands.


“A prince does not behave in such a manner,” his father lectured.

Once King Rhaegar Targaryen heard of the altercation, Aegon knew he would be in trouble. His father consistently reminded him and reprimanded him when he behaved as anything other than the Prince he was, and the King he was going to become.

“He said my mother was a savage,” Aegon pouted, kicking the wooden beam of his four-poster canopy bed, “I should have cut his tongue out like Ser Illyn’s—”

“That’s enough, Aegon!”

Jon paused in his steps, jumping up slightly from the sound of his father’s raised voice. Rhaegar Targaryen very rarely raised his voice at him, so he knew now that he had crossed a line.

“Forgive me, father, I was—”

“There’s nothing to forgive, child,” his father said, beckoning him to take a seat beside him on the soft, feather bed. Aegon slowly dragged his feet towards the bed, jumping up beside his father as he placed a strong arm around his small shoulders, “Viserys is your uncle, and as wrong as it was for him to say what he said, that does not warrant a reaction from you. If you are to be a King one day, you need to learn to take what others have to say about you in stride, you are above words.”

“He said I wasn’t a real Targaryen, because I don’t look like you.”

“Look at me,” his father ordered. Hesitantly, Aegon looked up into his father’s vibrant violet eyes, “You are a Targaryen. You have the blood of the dragon, but you’re also a wolf, just as your mother was. That does not change the fact that you will rule, and with ruling comes being wise to choose your battles, and strong enough to avoid the words that others have to say about you. You will marry Rhaenys, and together you will continue to build the Targaryen dynasty.”

Aegon’s brows furrowed at the words, “Rhaenys?”

“Are you not pleased?”

“It’s not— I just— why Rhaenys?”

His father’s silver brows crinkled at his question, “The Targaryens have always wed members of their families—”

“But you married my mother. And before that, Lady Elia. They weren’t members of your family,” Aegon pointed.

He could see the unrest in his father as he rubbed his face with his hand, smirking to himself in amusement, “Is this about Daenerys?”

“What? NO!” Jon shouted in embarrassment.

“I know you’re upset that Viserys is to marry her, I know that’s the reason why you’re not too fond of him and why you fight him every opportunity you get,” he said.

“I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

“Be that as it may, Daenerys is to wed Viserys when they come of age, and you will wed Rhaenys. She is of Dornish descent, and they did not take too kindly the fact that I annulled my marriage to Lady Elia. You must fix the mess I created with them.”

“Was it a mistake then, marrying my mother and having me?”

Aegon felt his father’s strong arms tighten around him, “You and your mother were never, and will never be mistakes.”

Aegon looked down at his feet, nodding. He wasn’t sure if he felt better, or worse.

“No more fighting with Viserys, promise me,” his father ordered.

Sighing, Aegon reluctantly nodded, “I promise.”

“Good, and I will make certain he puts an end to his vile behavior as well. In the meantime, you are confined to your quarters to think about what we’ve talked about and you’ve done. I’ll have the servants bring your supper.”

For hours after, the young boy stared up at the canopy of his bed, bored and frustrated with being locked in his room. The food that the servants brought him remained untouched on the table across his bed.

The sound of the gentle rapping coming from his door nudged him from his thoughtful stupor; his brows knitted in confusion when he saw her tiny figure emerge, a candle in her hand as she made her way towards his bed. He sat up, staring at the little girl with wide eyes, “Daenerys? What are you doing here?”

“I wanted to see how you were doing,” she whispered, bringing the candlelight to his face, observing the small marks that Viserys left on him, “You’re doing a lot better than Viserys.”

“Are you here to tell me I shouldn’t have—”

“I’m not here to tell you anything, other than sorry for what he said,” she gently said.

Aegon’s eyes narrowed in confusion, “Why are you sorry? It’s not your fault.”

“He’s jealous of you.”

“That still doesn’t have anything to do with you.”

“He knows you like me, Aegon,” she spoke, making the boy flinch at her boldness.

He swallowed hard as he stared at her, his voice a slight whisper as he replied, “That doesn’t give him a reason to be jealous.”

She smiled softly, placing the candle holder on the table next to the bed and crossing her legs as she leaned in, whispering a secret, “You’re going to be the King of the Seven Kingdoms, of all of Westeros, and he’s not. He thinks he deserves it more than you.”

“I don’t want to be king.”

“You’re going to be.”

Aegon’s deep brown eyes bore into the light, violet crystals that were Daenerys’s eyes. How could he not like her?

She was always beautiful, and kind. And bold. She was the only one who didn’t treat him as an outsider; even Rhaenys and Egg treated him like an outsider.

But not her.

“But I don’t want to.”

“We all have to do things we don’t want to, Aegon.”

His eyes flew back up to hers, “Like marry Viserys?”

He watched her tense at his name, and Aegon narrowed his eyes suspiciously, “I’ll do what I have to do. We’re Targaryens, and we all have a destiny.”

Aegon continued to stare at her as she was lost in deep thought, her brows furrowed and her fingers picking at the ends of her nightgown. Finally, she sighed and reached for her candle, “I must go, before I get into trouble.”

“Okay,” Jon sighed, heavily as he watched her carefully jump from the bed and tiptoe towards the door, “Daenerys?”

She turned, the candlelight reflecting her eyes like a pair of deep amethyst jewels, “Yes?”

He wasn’t sure if he should ask it. And he wasn’t sure if she would even tell him the truth if he had, but he wanted to. He wanted to so badly to know if she felt the same way about him, the way he did about her.

Instead, he exhaled, defeated as he simply said, “Goodnight.”

She smiled, kindly and warmly at him, “Goodnight, Prince Aegon.”


It was late, very late into the night when Aegon heard footsteps and the silent creaking of his door being pushed open. The room was dark, but in the darkness, he could feel the shadows moving across his bedroom floor.

His father always warned him to be prepared, because no one is ever safe, not even in their sleep. He reached for the dagger underneath his pillow, ready to fight whomever dared to enter the Prince’s bedroom.

He could hear breathing, heavy breathing, as though someone was carrying a large weight over his shoulders. He heard a flint being struck, and as the light of the candle went aflame, he grasped his dagger and immediately swung into the air in front of him, missing the man’s tunic by a mere inch.

“Is that how you greet the men who are trying to save your life?”

Aegon’s brows furrowed. He recognized that voice, “Lord Varys? What are you—”

“I know you have questions, my young prince, but time is of the essence and unfortunately, I don’t have time to answer all of them,” the bald man said as he nodded to the men on the other side of the bed, who tossed a body on the bed beside him.

Aegon jumped in surprise, watching as they unwrapped the body from the cloaks. The boy, whom no doubt was dead, bared a striking resemblance to him. His hair was dark, curly. His skin was the same ivory tone as his own, “What—what is this?”

“We’re saving your life, Your Grace. We need to get you out of King’s Landing, immediately.”

“But—”

“Your father is dead, if he hasn’t been murdered in his sleep he will be soon. And you along with him,” Varys said as he watched the men prepare the boy in the bed, laying him there, watching as the blood in his body now seeped into his clean sheets.

“My—my father? We need to do something! We need to—”

“I am doing the only thing I can do; I can’t save him, but I can save you. You can come with me now, or you can stay here and die.”

Aegon glanced down at the body beside him.

This could be you.

Everything inside of him told him to stand and fight. To go and protect his father, to live up to his name. But he was good with a sword, that didn’t mean he was the best swordsman alive. He would be cut to pieces if he dared to take on the phantom enemies in the castle.

There was a part of him that didn’t believe the spider, but there was also something like concern in the spymaster’s face. He had never seen him look so concerned.

Reluctantly, Aegon pushed the blankets off him and pulled the cloak that Lord Varys handed to him over his shoulders, bringing the hood down over his face until Varys was satisfied that he would not easily be identified.

He followed Lord Varys and the gang of men out of his chambers, the castle was silent as they proceeded in the darkness, occasionally pausing as they heard footsteps in the halls and hiding in a dark corner until it was safe to pass.

He was led down parts of the castle he didn’t know existed, plunging down further and further into the darkness until they eventually emerged into a small channel with a small rowboat bobbing in the water quietly, “This is where I leave you, Prince Aegon.”

“What? Why—”

“You will be safe with these men, they will take you somewhere far away, somewhere safe. There, you will learn the truth of what has happened tonight,” he said, “One day, you will return. But for now, stay hidden. Don’t speak to anyone about who you are, your life depends on it.”

Aegon swallowed hard and nodded in agreement. Lord Varys smiled, and bowed to him as the men pushed the rowboat away from the rocks and into the calm water, “Until the day we meet again.”

He watched with confused eyes as the men rowed him further and further out into the sea, the moonlight gleaming down on them, bathing them in a silver glow. The further they rowed out, the cleared the Red Keep became, and it was when he heard the bells begin to toll, that he knew Lord Varys spoke the truth about his father.

But… why?

Who would want to kill Rhaegar Targaryen?

What about his brother? His sister? Daenerys?

“Wait, we need to go back,” he ordered.

“Can’t do that little lad,” one of the rowers said, “Orders were to get you out, only you.”

“We need to! I left someone behind—”

“If we go back, you’ll die—”

“I don’t care! I need to go back for her! I need to protect her!”

Aegon began thrashing in the rowboat, readying himself to jump out and swim back to the red keep for her. But the strong arms around him kept him from doing so. He shouted, screamed, and begged for them to return, but every minute they moved further from the keep and out into the vast openness of the sea.

Once the Keep was nothing but a small speck in the distance, he stopped fighting and resigned himself to his tears, thinking of those violet eyes, and the silver hair he would never see again. Thinking of the puffy pink lips he would never kiss.

The soft hands he would never feel against his skin.

Her gentle smile that always made him feel weak and tremble.

He thought about her; about all the times they played together, all the times she helped him work on his penmanship, all the times she told him she wished she could sword fight, and he obliged, handing her his wooden sword and teaching her the ways of swordsmanship.

He was vaguely aware of being pushed up the ladder of the side of ship, he didn’t pay any mind to the sails, or the colors of the sails. All he could think of was his father, and her.

The Keep was not visible from where he was now, all he saw was the moonlight reflecting the surface of the water in a silver light, like the color of her hair.

His breathing was heavy as he lowered his hood and stared up at the moon, making a silent promise not only to himself, but to his father, and to her.

If you’re alive, I’ll come back for you.

It was all he could do as he sailed out in the unknown, in the middle of the night.

Amidst the chaos and the shouting, he lost interest in Viserys Targaryen. His own eyes fell on another pair of violet eyes, eyes that glanced at him with sorrow and remorse as she kneeled beside her brother, brushing his hair back in her hands.


“A prince does not behave in such a manner,” his father lectured.

Once King Rhaegar Targaryen heard of the altercation, Aegon knew he would be in trouble. His father consistently reminded him and reprimanded him when he behaved as anything other than the Prince he was, and the King he was going to become.

“He said my mother was a savage,” Aegon pouted, kicking the wooden beam of his four-poster canopy bed, “I should have cut his tongue out like Ser Illyn’s—”

“That’s enough, Aegon!”

Jon paused in his steps, jumping up slightly from the sound of his father’s raised voice. Rhaegar Targaryen very rarely raised his voice at him, so he knew now that he had crossed a line.

“Forgive me, father, I was—”

“There’s nothing to forgive, child,” his father said, beckoning him to take a seat beside him on the soft, feather bed. Aegon slowly dragged his feet towards the bed, jumping up beside his father as he placed a strong arm around his small shoulders, “Viserys is your uncle, and as wrong as it was for him to say what he said, that does not warrant a reaction from you. If you are to be a King one day, you need to learn to take what others have to say about you in stride, you are above words.”

“He said I wasn’t a real Targaryen, because I don’t look like you.”

“Look at me,” his father ordered. Hesitantly, Aegon looked up into his father’s vibrant violet eyes, “You are a Targaryen. You have the blood of the dragon, but you’re also a wolf, just as your mother was. That does not change the fact that you will rule, and with ruling comes being wise to choose your battles, and strong enough to avoid the words that others have to say about you. You will marry Rhaenys, and together you will continue to build the Targaryen dynasty.”

Aegon’s brows furrowed at the words, “Rhaenys?”

“Are you not pleased?”

“It’s not— I just— why Rhaenys?”

His father’s silver brows crinkled at his question, “The Targaryens have always wed members of their families—”

“But you married my mother. And before that, Lady Elia. They weren’t members of your family,” Aegon pointed.

He could see the unrest in his father as he rubbed his face with his hand, smirking to himself in amusement, “Is this about Daenerys?”

“What? NO!” Jon shouted in embarrassment.

“I know you’re upset that Viserys is to marry her, I know that’s the reason why you’re not too fond of him and why you fight him every opportunity you get,” he said.

“I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

“Be that as it may, Daenerys is to wed Viserys when they come of age, and you will wed Rhaenys. She is of Dornish descent, and they did not take too kindly the fact that I annulled my marriage to Lady Elia. You must fix the mess I created with them.”

“Was it a mistake then, marrying my mother and having me?”

Aegon felt his father’s strong arms tighten around him, “You and your mother were never, and will never be mistakes.”

Aegon looked down at his feet, nodding. He wasn’t sure if he felt better, or worse.

“No more fighting with Viserys, promise me,” his father ordered.

Sighing, Aegon reluctantly nodded, “I promise.”

“Good, and I will make certain he puts an end to his vile behavior as well. In the meantime, you are confined to your quarters to think about what we’ve talked about and you’ve done. I’ll have the servants bring your supper.”

For hours after, the young boy stared up at the canopy of his bed, bored and frustrated with being locked in his room. The food that the servants brought him remained untouched on the table across his bed.

The sound of the gentle rapping coming from his door nudged him from his thoughtful stupor; his brows knitted in confusion when he saw her tiny figure emerge, a candle in her hand as she made her way towards his bed. He sat up, staring at the little girl with wide eyes, “Daenerys? What are you doing here?”

“I wanted to see how you were doing,” she whispered, bringing the candlelight to his face, observing the small marks that Viserys left on him, “You’re doing a lot better than Viserys.”

“Are you here to tell me I shouldn’t have—”

“I’m not here to tell you anything, other than sorry for what he said,” she gently said.

Aegon’s eyes narrowed in confusion, “Why are you sorry? It’s not your fault.”

“He’s jealous of you.”

“That still doesn’t have anything to do with you.”

“He knows you like me, Aegon,” she spoke, making the boy flinch at her boldness.

He swallowed hard as he stared at her, his voice a slight whisper as he replied, “That doesn’t give him a reason to be jealous.”

She smiled softly, placing the candle holder on the table next to the bed and crossing her legs as she leaned in, whispering a secret, “You’re going to be the King of the Seven Kingdoms, of all of Westeros, and he’s not. He thinks he deserves it more than you.”

“I don’t want to be king.”

“You’re going to be.”

Aegon’s deep brown eyes bore into the light, violet crystals that were Daenerys’s eyes. How could he not like her?

She was always beautiful, and kind. And bold. She was the only one who didn’t treat him as an outsider; even Rhaenys and Egg treated him like an outsider.

But not her.

“But I don’t want to.”

“We all have to do things we don’t want to, Aegon.”

His eyes flew back up to hers, “Like marry Viserys?”

He watched her tense at his name, and Aegon narrowed his eyes suspiciously, “I’ll do what I have to do. We’re Targaryens, and we all have a destiny.”

Aegon continued to stare at her as she was lost in deep thought, her brows furrowed and her fingers picking at the ends of her nightgown. Finally, she sighed and reached for her candle, “I must go, before I get into trouble.”

“Okay,” Jon sighed, heavily as he watched her carefully jump from the bed and tiptoe towards the door, “Daenerys?”

She turned, the candlelight reflecting her eyes like a pair of deep amethyst jewels, “Yes?”

He wasn’t sure if he should ask it. And he wasn’t sure if she would even tell him the truth if he had, but he wanted to. He wanted to so badly to know if she felt the same way about him, the way he did about her.

Instead, he exhaled, defeated as he simply said, “Goodnight.”

She smiled, kindly and warmly at him, “Goodnight, Prince Aegon.”


It was late, very late into the night when Aegon heard footsteps and the silent creaking of his door being pushed open. The room was dark, but in the darkness, he could feel the shadows moving across his bedroom floor.

His father always warned him to be prepared, because no one is ever safe, not even in their sleep. He reached for the dagger underneath his pillow, ready to fight whomever dared to enter the Prince’s bedroom.

He could hear breathing, heavy breathing, as though someone was carrying a large weight over his shoulders. He heard a flint being struck, and as the light of the candle went aflame, he grasped his dagger and immediately swung into the air in front of him, missing the man’s tunic by a mere inch.

“Is that how you greet the men who are trying to save your life?”

Aegon’s brows furrowed. He recognized that voice, “Lord Varys? What are you—”

“I know you have questions, my young prince, but time is of the essence and unfortunately, I don’t have time to answer all of them,” the bald man said as he nodded to the men on the other side of the bed, who tossed a body on the bed beside him.

Aegon jumped in surprise, watching as they unwrapped the body from the cloaks. The boy, whom no doubt was dead, bared a striking resemblance to him. His hair was dark, curly. His skin was the same ivory tone as his own, “What—what is this?”

“We’re saving your life, Your Grace. We need to get you out of King’s Landing, immediately.”

“But—”

“Your father is dead, if he hasn’t been murdered in his sleep he will be soon. And you along with him,” Varys said as he watched the men prepare the boy in the bed, laying him there, watching as the blood in his body now seeped into his clean sheets.

“My—my father? We need to do something! We need to—”

“I am doing the only thing I can do; I can’t save him, but I can save you. You can come with me now, or you can stay here and die.”

Aegon glanced down at the body beside him.

This could be you.

Everything inside of him told him to stand and fight. To go and protect his father, to live up to his name. But he was good with a sword, that didn’t mean he was the best swordsman alive. He would be cut to pieces if he dared to take on the phantom enemies in the castle.

There was a part of him that didn’t believe the spider, but there was also something like concern in the spymaster’s face. He had never seen him look so concerned.

Reluctantly, Aegon pushed the blankets off him and pulled the cloak that Lord Varys handed to him over his shoulders, bringing the hood down over his face until Varys was satisfied that he would not easily be identified.

He followed Lord Varys and the gang of men out of his chambers, the castle was silent as they proceeded in the darkness, occasionally pausing as they heard footsteps in the halls and hiding in a dark corner until it was safe to pass.

He was led down parts of the castle he didn’t know existed, plunging down further and further into the darkness until they eventually emerged into a small channel with a small rowboat bobbing in the water quietly, “This is where I leave you, Prince Aegon.”

“What? Why—”

“You will be safe with these men, they will take you somewhere far away, somewhere safe. There, you will learn the truth of what has happened tonight,” he said, “One day, you will return. But for now, stay hidden. Don’t speak to anyone about who you are, your life depends on it.”

Aegon swallowed hard and nodded in agreement. Lord Varys smiled, and bowed to him as the men pushed the rowboat away from the rocks and into the calm water, “Until the day we meet again.”

He watched with confused eyes as the men rowed him further and further out into the sea, the moonlight gleaming down on them, bathing them in a silver glow. The further they rowed out, the cleared the Red Keep became, and it was when he heard the bells begin to toll, that he knew Lord Varys spoke the truth about his father.

But… why?

Who would want to kill Rhaegar Targaryen?

What about his brother? His sister? Daenerys?

“Wait, we need to go back,” he ordered.

“Can’t do that little lad,” one of the rowers said, “Orders were to get you out, only you.”

“We need to! I left someone behind—”

“If we go back, you’ll die—”

“I don’t care! I need to go back for her! I need to protect her!”

Aegon began thrashing in the rowboat, readying himself to jump out and swim back to the red keep for her. But the strong arms around him kept him from doing so. He shouted, screamed, and begged for them to return, but every minute they moved further from the keep and out into the vast openness of the sea.

Once the Keep was nothing but a small speck in the distance, he stopped fighting and resigned himself to his tears, thinking of those violet eyes, and the silver hair he would never see again. Thinking of the puffy pink lips he would never kiss.

The soft hands he would never feel against his skin.

Her gentle smile that always made him feel weak and tremble.

He thought about her; about all the times they played together, all the times she helped him work on his penmanship, all the times she told him she wished she could sword fight, and he obliged, handing her his wooden sword and teaching her the ways of swordsmanship.

He was vaguely aware of being pushed up the ladder of the side of ship, he didn’t pay any mind to the sails, or the colors of the sails. All he could think of was his father, and her.

The Keep was not visible from where he was now, all he saw was the moonlight reflecting the surface of the water in a silver light, like the color of her hair.

His breathing was heavy as he lowered his hood and stared up at the moon, making a silent promise not only to himself, but to his father, and to her.

If you’re alive, I’ll come back for you.

It was all he could do as he sailed out in the unknown, in the middle of the night.

Wrath of the Dragon

Rheagar Targaryen

She was born while the bells of King’s Landing rang, loud and clear amid the storm that swallowed the shores. The thunderous claps of the sky filled the ears of the people in the city, along with Rheagar’s who watched as his little sister was born; a silver haired beauty with puffy pink lips, swollen from the journey she made into the world.

He watched as his mother lay in the birthing bed, unmoving and stiff. The color from her rose kissed cheeks was dulling to a pale white as blood soaked into the fine sheets that would take the servants weeks to wash out. He would have to burn them, he didn’t want them around. He didn’t want to remember how he lost his mother.

The gods, if there were any, were cruel to take his mother from him in the same fashion that they took his beloved, Lyanna.

He recalled that night all too well. The way she whimpered quietly as she pleaded with Rhaegar to take care of her child. How she cried softly at the sight of the raven-haired boy gently nestled in Rheagar’s strong arms. And then the quiet intake of her last breath as the Stranger took her.

In the empty halls of the Red Keep, the wind whistled, and the rain pattered against the hard stone, he could vaguely hear the whisper of her voice once more. Of his Lyanna, his winter rose.

The whispers were drowned out by the sounds of his father’s shouting coming from his own room, “Burn them all!”

He sighed heavily as he held his little sister in his hands, his mind feeling as though it would sooner fall out of its place in his skull the longer, he heard the shouts. He wondered if he could quell the unrest that was stirring within the kingdoms.

It was no secret that King Aerys was… unruly. Even he was filled with unease whenever the thought that his father might become more unhinged plagued him.

In the darkness, in his own quarters that he shared with Lyanna, he knew his own son, Aegon, slept soundly.

So close in age.

One of fire, and one of ice.

He took after his mother, with the dark hair and the dark eyes. He was a northerner. A true northerner. If there was a splash of his own Targaryen blood within his own child, it would be in his character. It would be in how he chose to lead.

He had to do something. Not just for his sister, or his son, but for the people of Westeros. He had to take the throne from his father and rule, as much as he dreaded it. As much as he’d rather lay in the ground with his beloved Lyanna, he had to fulfill his destiny. As did his sister. His brother. And his son.

“Burn them all!”

The words made him cringe inside, and cool chill traveled up his spine as he slowly closed his eyes, sighing heavily with sorrow.

Gently, he handed his baby sister, Daenerys, to the wet nurse that watched him with sad eyes, “See to it that she’s well taken care of. I will be back for her in the morning.”

“Of course, Your Grace,” the older lady squeaked as she took the child from him.

Like the proud prince that he was, his head held high and the Targaryen blood of the dragon flowing though him, he glided his way to his father’s quarters, his resolve stiff and true.

He had to do the right thing.



Aegon Targaryen

A boy of ten with a full head of curls and deep brown eyes watched the young girl with flowing silver hair from the other end of the table as she practiced her penmanship. She sat beside his brother, Egg, and his sister Rhaenys. But his attention wasn’t on them, it was on her; he watched as her delicate hand curved the letters on the parchment, glistening with ink in the bright sunlight that shone through the open courtyard as Grand Maester Pycelle droned on about the lineage and ancestry of the Targaryens, and their dominion over Westeros.

It was a story he’d heard many times before, he could recite the stories in his head word for word the way Grand Maester Pycelle spoke them, in his old, exhausted, heavy voice.

The Grand Maester’s words were echoes in his ears, his eyes focused on the girl as she listened intently to what the old man said, although she had heard them many times before. She remained patient, in awe, as if all of this was the first time, she had heard it spoken. She loved the stories, he recalled. She had told him as such. She had always dreamed of having her own dragons to ride, of course, that would be impossible.

All the dragons were dead.

“I, I must say it is time for a spot of lunch,” Pycelle droned, bringing Jon out of his thought process, aware that Daenerys’ eyes immediately shot up to meet his. His eyes darted to the stones on the ground, watching the toes of his fine leather boots with too much concentration.

He could feel her watching him with those kind violet eyes of hers. From the corner of his eye, he could see the gentlest of smiles begin to cross her puffy, pink lips.

“Egg Jon!”

His head immediately shot up to glance at Viserys Targaryen gallanting towards him, wooden swords clutched in each hand. He stared at the boy, almost with envy. Viserys was his uncle, and though the silver haired boy was 5 years older than he, and they were rivaled in the art of swordsmanship, everyone secretly agreed that Aegon was better.

But he had the regal Targaryen look that his father had; violet eyes, silver hair. They were beautiful, there was no denying that. And Viserys made sure to remind him that he was an outsider.

“You’re not a true Targaryen, look at you, you don’t even have the looks of a king,” he would say as he puffed his chest out and adjusted his silks and leather, “Not like me.”

Aegon turned and glanced down at the drying ink on parchment as he worked on his penmanship, “What do you want Viserys?”

“Let’s spar,” he said, tapping him on the back with a wooden sword, “C’mon, I’ve been practicing, and I need someone to knock into the dirt.”

“I’m busy,” Aegon sighed, writing his name on the parchment.

Aegon Targaryen.

Eh-Jon was how he pronounced it, not Egg-On.

Grand Maester Pycelle breathed heavily as he began, “N-now children—”

A sudden sting shot up from his hand to his arm as the wooden sword came down on him, hard. Jon shouted in agony, and in an instant, Viserys was on the ground as Jon’s fist connected with his stupid, kingly face.

Stupid boy.

Stupid silver haired boy.

Stupid Targaryens.

Aegon swallowed hard and nodded in agreement. Lord Varys smiled, and bowed to him as the men pushed the rowboat away from the rocks and into the calm water, “Until the day we meet again.”

He watched with confused eyes as the men rowed him further and further out into the sea, the moonlight gleaming down on them, bathing them in a silver glow. The further they rowed out, the cleared the Red Keep became, and it was when he heard the bells begin to toll, that he knew Lord Varys spoke the truth about his father.

But… why?

Who would want to kill Rhaegar Targaryen?

What about his brother? His sister? Daenerys?

“Wait, we need to go back,” he ordered.

“Can’t do that little lad,” one of the rowers said, “Orders were to get you out, only you.”

“We need to! I left someone behind—”

“If we go back, you’ll die—”

“I don’t care! I need to go back for her! I need to protect her!”

Aegon began thrashing in the rowboat, readying himself to jump out and swim back to the red keep for her. But the strong arms around him kept him from doing so. He shouted, screamed, and begged for them to return, but every minute they moved further from the keep and out into the vast openness of the sea.

Once the Keep was nothing but a small speck in the distance, he stopped fighting and resigned himself to his tears, thinking of those violet eyes, and the silver hair he would never see again. Thinking of the puffy pink lips he would never kiss.

The soft hands he would never feel against his skin.

Her gentle smile that always made him feel weak and tremble.

He thought about her; about all the times they played together, all the times she helped him work on his penmanship, all the times she told him she wished she could sword fight, and he obliged, handing her his wooden sword and teaching her the ways of swordsmanship.

He was vaguely aware of being pushed up the ladder of the side of ship, he didn’t pay any mind to the sails, or the colors of the sails. All he could think of was his father, and her.

The Keep was not visible from where he was now, all he saw was the moonlight reflecting the surface of the water in a silver light, like the color of her hair.

His breathing was heavy as he lowered his hood and stared up at the moon, making a silent promise not only to himself, but to his father, and to her.

If you’re alive, I’ll come back for you.

It was all he could do as he sailed out in the unknown, in the middle of the night.

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: The kingdom I came from didn’t care about words. What my father learned, I am to learn again in a lifetime. He could only give...
caption:
The kingdom I came from didn’t care about words. What my father learned, I am to learn again in a lifetime. He could only give me what his memory allowed him and even if sparse and unreliable spoken words reached me, I could only pass it on to a few people.

We only started to realise it. Words create lasting movements. Progress, religions, philosophies were made possible with words and this is not getting away.

Tyrion understands it, so he keeps reading more books and George might never stop writing stories.
✒
